Final two named to Mass. gambling commission

State officials have named a retired state Appeals Court judge and a former Springfield city official to the final two seats on the five-member panel. (Globe, 10:26 a.m.)

Prospective employers asking
applicants for Facebook passwords

Some companies and agencies are going beyond glancing at applicants' social networking profiles, asking to log in as the user to have a look around. (AP, 7:40 a.m.)

Jurors in Mattapan massacre ordered
by judge to resume deliberations

The jury returned today in hopes of breaking their deadlock on nine of the 19 charges filed against the two men in the quadruple murder trial. (Globe, 10:33 a.m.)

Mitt Romney said his background makes him uniquely qualified to be president. Rick Santorum said the former Mass. governor is beholden to Wall Street. (Boston Globe)

South End robbery leaves cabbie stabbed; three wounded in separate fight

A cab driver was stabbed allegedly by two passengers in the South End, while a fight in Dorchester last night left three men with stab wounds. (Globe, 9:38 a.m.)

NCAA finds enthusiastic
audience in Boston

Above all, Boston sports fans embrace history-making events. That helps explain the draw of the NCAA East Regional, which starts Thursday at TD Garden.

Mitt Romney’s Medicare plan
could create gap for seniors

By raising the eligibility age while removing a new safety net for the ailing to obtain affordable insurance, Romney’s plan would result in more uninsured seniors.

Mass. plans to update adult education

Massachusetts education officials are planning to retool adult basic-education programs to focus more on preparing students for college or further job training.

Historic church could avert auction

OneUnited Bank plans to auction the Charles Street AME Church in Roxbury on Thursday, but specialists say the foreclosed church has a number of options.
Opinion | Paul McMorrow

OneUnited bailout didn’t help Boston

The nation's largest black-owned bank has long lacked any significant banking activity in Boston.

Youth Underground offers teens the chance to blossom in its ensemble theatrical productions in Cambridge.

Artists dabble collectively in whimsy

Attacks in 8 Iraq cities kill 46
